body: DRIVING northward through the Bekaa, a valley habitually mentioned in the same breath as Hezbollah, hashish and hostages, I felt a little peculiar discussing the abundant varieties of traditional Lebanese cooking. But my guide for the day, Ramzi Shwayri, Lebanon's most famous chef and a television star throughout the region, radiates infectious
title: In a Lebanese Valley, A Star Chef's Tour

author: Roy Hoffman, who lives in Point Clear, Ala., is the author of the forthcoming novel, ''Chicken Dreaming Corn'' (Hill Street Press).
body: UP the 46 steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's main staircase, through the halls of sumptuous European paintings, there is a space, somber and mystical, I call my own. On the walls of its two, linked galleries are portraits deeply familiar to me. One of the canvases, ''Woman With a Pink,'' shows a pensive woman holding a carnation; another,
title: My Own Private New York

body: LARRY MUFSON'S friends have described him, not totally approvingly, as a serial renovator. To some people, the idea of continual renovation smacks of masochism or neurosis. But Mr. Mufson is not in fact a serial renovator. He is a simultaneous renovator. He is, for instance, just finishing a town house on East 30th Street, where he lives with Betsy
title: Habitats/East 30th Street; An Architect Who Enjoys The Act of Renovating

body: Preparing for a possible transit strike on Monday, FleetBoston Financial has hired four buses to bring employees from the four other boroughs into Manhattan. The free transportation is not a perk to pamper high-paid executives; it is insurance that 200 lower-wage workers like bank tellers and security guards can get to the company's 23 Manhattan
title: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: COMMUTERS; Car Pools, Hired Buses and E-Mail From Home

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. Currently on view, ''Looking Back at Clear Comfort,'' photographs Austen took of the house (formerly called Clear Comfort)
title: SPARE TIMES

author: E-mail: anemona@nytimes.com
body: IN its current issue, Business Week lists America's 50 most generous philanthropists. Bill and Melinda Gates rank No. 1, for supporting health and education; George Soros is No. 6, for promoting open and free societies. Mayor Bloomberg made the top 50 on the Forbes list of richest Americans, at No. 29 this year. He has said he gave $122 million to
title: COPING; Nuisance to the Rich, Worse to the Poor

body: TAD HILLS and Lee Wade weren't looking for a place to live. But as sometimes happens, a house found them. They were happily ensconced in their three-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn Heights when Christine Dugan, a broker for William B. May who had sold them their place seven years earlier, called and said that she had a house that would soon be for
title: Habitats/Dean Street, Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; A House That Landed Right on Their Doorstep

body: In a cramped fourth-floor walk-up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a roomful of young comics crack one another up. They're not telling jokes, however. They're pitching ideas for Jest, a monthly humor magazine whose first issue appeared this month. They wonder: How about a ''Pigeon in the Street'' piece asking that perennial New York question, ''Where are
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Remember, This Is How The New Yorker Started

body: To the Editor: Most of the parents interviewed seemed to think going to the playground was all about them: ''How does anyone make friends around here?'' ''The nannies tend to ostracize you.'' ''I'd rather be reading a magazine.'' ''It's like high school all over again.'' Who are these people? And what sort of example are they setting for their
title: Not So Jaded By Playground Duty

body: ONCE upon a time, possibly at a lodge in Wyoming, possibly at a butcher shop in Maurice, La., or maybe even at a plantation in South Carolina, an enterprising cook decided to take a boned chicken, a boned duck and a boned turkey, stuff them one inside the other like Russian dolls, and roast them. He called his masterpiece turducken. In the years
title: Turkey Finds Its Inner Duck (and Chicken)

body: In East Harlem, posters have been taped to the door of the 19th-century red-stone firehouse that is home to Engine Company 36. Political leaders from Representative Charles B. Rangel to the Rev. Al Sharpton have been called. Fliers have been handed out. Firefighters have been facing the media, somber and indignant. Engine Company 36 on 125th Street
title: As Closings Loom, Firefighters Try to Rally Neighbors

body: Eight fire companies would be disbanded as part of a $51 million reduction in the Fire Department's $1 billion budget. The closings would save the department $10.8 million, but could not take place before a 45-day public review. The companies slated for closing are: in Brooklyn, Engine 204 in Cobble Hill, Engine 212 in Greenpoint, Engine 278 in
title: THE MAYOR'S BUDGET PLAN: SPENDING; Fire Department

body: WHO -- Steven Prior, a building contractor. WHAT -- A two-bedroom carriage house. WHERE -- Cleveland Heights, Ohio I've been in this house for two years. It was a project for my company, Hts Home Detailing. The owners' intention was to redo it as an in-law suite. Then they decided that they should turn it into a rental unit to make extra income. I
title: HAVENS: LIVING HERE; Carriage Houses: Great-Granddad's Garage Moves to the Foreground

body: THE SETTING -- Tatiana, a Russian restaurant on the boardwalk in Brighton Beach. THE BUZZ -- ''Pick a card, any card,'' said Mr. Varkonyi, as
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BRIGHTON BEACH -- BUZZ; A Small-Stakes Poker Player Takes a Pot From Vegas Sharks

body: THE F train packed at day's end with 20-something commuters rumbles toward Brooklyn, but passengers look animated, not exhausted, and chat away as though they're off on a college football weekend. They are living out their dreams of making it in New York City even though they cannot afford Manhattan rents and often make the commute twice a day --
title: After Graduation, Lessons in Renting

author: Roy Hoffman lives in Mobile, Ala., and writes for The Mobile Register. His novel, ''Chicken Dreaming Corn'' (Hill St. Press), inspired in part by his grandparents' journey from Romania to Brooklyn, N.Y., to Alabama, will be published this winter.
body: YOU might think it's in the middle of nowhere -- down a two-lane Alabama highway lined with pine trees, farmhouses and mobile homes -- but to Janice Matthews and a hundred or so other residents of this crossroads with one general store and a gas pump, it's Brooklyn. ''Our Brooklyn,'' says Janice, petite, fair-haired and chatty, who runs Janice's
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Greetings From Brooklyn, Ala.

body: STACY MORRISON does not take furniture lightly. ''You have to commit to it,'' said Ms. Morrison, who bought her first grown-up piece, an overstuffed sofa bed with a skirt and deep cushions, nine years ago. ''I have crazy sentimental feelings,'' she added. When the sofa bed's original ivory-on-beige damask slipcover grew tattered and its cushions
title: TRADE SECRETS; Saving Sprung Seats

body: Of the 18 Civil Court judgeships up for election in New York City this November, only six are being contested in next week's Democratic primary. As a practical matter, that means the remaining dozen seats will be filled by men and women deeply beholden to the party pols who gave them a berth on the Democratic line and a virtually uncontested ride
title: For Civil Court in Brooklyn

body: Hold it right there -- don't even think about pocketing that change. There's another tip jar, sitting right next to the cash register, one of the many that have multiplied across the city, showing up at coffee counters, video stores, even the doggie day care center. They squat on the counter with an air of reproach -- and that, of course, is the
title: Here's Your Change; Give It Back; Those Countertop Jars Strain the Etiquette of Tipping

body: City Councilman Angel Rodriguez of Brooklyn resigned his post yesterday as he prepared to plead guilty to federal charges that he took bribes in exchange for throwing his support behind a supermarket project in Red Hook that he had once opposed. Mr. Rodriguez, who was a serious contender to become speaker of the City Council earlier this year, now
title: Councilman in Bribery Case Resigns on Eve of Guilty Plea

body: STEVEN BANKS, a Legal Aid Society lawyer who represents the homeless, sits at the large kitchen table with his wife, a housing court judge whose hair is still damp from the shower. His 11-year-old daughter is slurping up Lucky Charms cereal, while his 14-year-old son, arms folded, is making wisecracks about his workaholic father. Mr. Banks, 45,
title: PUBLIC LIVES; And in This Corner, Representing the Homeless . . .

body: Lillian Goldman, who made a major contribution to the reconstruction of the library at Yale Law School, in part because it was among the first law schools in America to admit women, died yesterday at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 80. The cause was pancreatic cancer, the family said. In 1992, Mrs. Goldman gave Yale University Law School
title: Lillian Goldman, 80, Yale Law School Donor and Advocate for Women's Education

title: PULSE; Coolness, Cubed

author: Michael Shapiro's next book, ''The Last Good Season: Brooklyn, the Dodgers and Their Final Pennant Race Together,'' is due out next year.
body: I was 4 years old when the Dodgers left Brooklyn, but unlike the team, I stayed. I never went to Ebbets Field. I never even saw it. I lived in Brooklyn until I was 21 and when I, too, finally left, I did so still believing that had the Dodgers not abandoned the borough for Los Angeles, Brooklyn would have been altogether different, not the flat,
title: MY BROOKLYN; The Team That's Filling the Void the Dodgers Left Behind

body: THE best moment is swooping south on the F.D.R. Drive, just before the Manhattan Bridge, when the highway elevates again and it is like you are in a little airplane taking off. title: No Particular Place to Go

body: When the July heat gathers force, it will be harvest time for Fred Duchac. Then he will climb up a narrow stepladder through a hatchway in his third-floor bathroom and onto his rooftop. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; From a City Roof, a Crop Well Worth the Occasional Ouch

title: Where Home Is a Real Sanctuary

author: Paula Fox is a novelist whose 2001 memoir, ''Borrowed Finery,'' will be published in paperback in October. Her novel ''The God of Nightmares'' was just reissued.
body: ONE of the welcome, sometimes even thrilling, consequences of publishing a memoir is hearing unexpectedly from readers who once figured in your life. Last year I published ''Borrowed Finery,'' in which I attempted to tell the story of my first 20 years. I write ''attempted,'' because language is insufficient to do more than suggest the depths and
title: ESSAY; Amazement and Memory

He said he planned to hold tastings in the shop with foods from the market and would convert part of the restaurant in Eli's Manhattan to a wine bar. Another Basil The

body: YOU'VE got to know when to hold 'em and know when to fold 'em. That may seem a tired old line, but it is a fundamental rule of poker. It also happens to serve pretty well in life, which Robert Varkonyi will tell you has a way of resembling what the poet-songwriter Leonard Cohen once called ''the holy game of poker.'' Mr. Varkonyi has a point. Even
title: NYC; Luck Deals An Amateur $2 Million

body: The Manhattan skyline has a new logo, but viewers from Manhattan and Brooklyn are not buying it. Verizon recently removed the old bell symbol from its windowless skyscraper at 375 Pearl Street, near the Brooklyn Bridge anchorage. It was replaced with a swooshlike logo, a scarlet checkmark with the company's name spelled out in 8.5-foot type.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK SIGNS; Verizon Lays Ma Bell to Rest With a Very Visible Swoosh

body: To the Editor: In your article on school choice, ''Pick One'' (April 28), you focused on largely English-speaking, white, upper-middle-class neighborhoods, Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. We live in a more economically and ethnically diverse neighborhood, Ditmas Park, and faced the choice of public or private for our son. Many home-buyers
title: Public, Private: What's a Parent to Do?

body: A CENTURY ago, Carroll Gardens was a working-class neighborhood in Brooklyn, home to thousands of Irish immigrants. In the decades before World War II, the Irish moved out and first-generation Italians moved in. The neighborhood kept its Italian-American character for decades and to a large degree retains it still. But in recent years a new group
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Carroll Gardens; Area of Gardens and 19th-Century Charm

title: Measuring a Downturn With a Show of Paws

body: Like a relentless drama too painful to watch but too compelling to turn away from, the conflict in the Middle East has put knots in New York-area residents' stomachs and suicide bombers in their nightmares. The turmoil is geographically distant, they say, but with its echoes of Sept. 11, and its passion, it is emotionally all too close. People
title: MIDEAST TURMOIL: VOICES; New Yorkers Tell of Fear, Anger and Fatigue Over Mideast

body: Nothing about Maria Paredes would arouse suspicion. A pleasant-looking woman with a friendly smile, she hardly seems a rule breaker. Still, alarm bells rang in the security guard's head when she approached him on a recent Sunday, a shopping bag slung over one arm. '' 'Open it and let me see inside,' '' she said he ordered. The guard, Mario Coggins,
title: The Snack Police Are Out in Force; But Messy Food Is Allowed if You Buy It at the Movies

body: A Brooklyn councilman who was recently a contender for City Council speaker was charged yesterday with demanding a $1.5 million break on a real estate deal from a developer in exchange for supporting the multimillion-dollar renovation of a waterfront warehouse in his district. The councilman, Angel Rodriguez, a Democrat, represents the Red Hook
title: Brooklyn Councilman Is Charged in an Extortion Scheme

body: THE Brooklyn dining scene has changed drastically in a decade. In a trickle that has swelled to a flood, Manhattan exiles have colonized every available block in formerly fringe areas off Park Slope and Cobble Hill, taking their money and appetites with them. Not surprisingly, a new generation of restaurants has arisen, seemingly overnight, to
title: RESTAURANTS; A Fresh Start For a Pioneer Of Park Slope

body: Enraged by the loud horn-honking outside his Cobble Hill apartment, Aaron Naparstek first started pelting cars with eggs. Then a driver threatened to come back and kill him in his sleep. So he thought it wise to try a gentler, more Zen tactic: he started writing haikus. For three months, Mr. Naparstek, 31, has been taping his antihonking verses --
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; Cars Howl on Choked Streets But Lamppost Poets Propose Gentler Paths to Work

title: COPING; Some Beautiful Minds Talk About Acceptance

body: BLOCK after block, the quiet streets of Boerum Hill, in northwest Brooklyn, are lined with shade trees and three- and four-story brick town houses, retaining the small-scale residential charm of a century ago. ''It's a well-preserved, mid-19th century brownstone community that is in the shadows of Brooklyn Heights and yet remains relatively
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Boerum Hill; Neighborhood With a 19th-Century Feel

body: NICKERSON-Eugene H. Of Roslyn, NY died Jan. 1, 2002. Survived by his wife, his four daughters, five grandchildren, and three brothers. Memorial service on Saturday 11:00 AM, Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Cobble Hill Health Center, 380 Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201, or
title: Paid Notice: Deaths NICKERSON, EUGENE H.

body: Lisa Sam returned home from school one day in March 1998 and thought something was wrong. ''I heard stomping upstairs,'' she said. ''My father was like, 'Go get some water!' '' There was a fire burning in her family's house in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Wellington Sam Jr., Lisa's father, tried to put out the fire, first by stomping on it, then with
title: The Neediest Cases; A Family in Distress Learns to Communicate Again
